title: Crystal structure of the BEACH domain reveals an unusual fold and extensive association with a novel PH domain
authors: Jogl G, Shen Y, Gebauer D, Li J, Wiegmann K, Kashkar H, Krönke M, Tong L
keyAssumptions: BEACH domains function as scaffolding elements; PH and BEACH domains are separate functional units
keyHypotheses: PH-BEACH domains form integrated structural unit with functional groove for ligand binding
strengths: First high-resolution structure; reveals unusual fold; demonstrates extensive domain-domain interface
weaknesses: Static structure only; no dynamic information; assumes rigid domain coupling
notes: Foundational structural study establishing PH-BEACH as functional unit, but assumes static interaction. Supports our coupling hypothesis structurally but lacks dynamic perspective.

title: BEACH domain proteins in membrane trafficking and disease
keyAssumptions: BEACH proteins primarily function in vesicle trafficking; disease mechanisms involve simple loss of function
keyHypotheses: BEACH proteins are multi-pathway regulators with complex disease mechanisms involving network disruption
strengths: Comprehensive recent review; integrates multiple functional studies; identifies research gaps
weaknesses: Review format limits mechanistic depth; some speculation on regulatory mechanisms
citation: Pereira C, Gershlick DC. J Cell Biol. 2024;223(12):e202410147
notes: Strong support for dynamic regulation hypothesis. Demonstrates multi-pathway coordination consistent with allosteric networks rather than static scaffolding.

title: Arf1-dependent LRBA recruitment to Rab4 endosomes is required for endolysosome homeostasis
authors: Szentgyörgyi V, Lueck LM, Overwijn D, Ritz D, Zoeller N, Patino-Lopez G, Shaw PJ, Warnatz K, Grimbacher B, Frauenknecht K, Rethwilm M, Rohr KB, Rolink AG, Hennet T, Spang A
keyAssumptions: BEACH proteins constitutively associate with membranes; function independent of GTPase regulation
keyHypotheses: LRBA recruitment is dynamically regulated by Arf1 activation state, enabling context-dependent function
strengths: Direct demonstration of regulated recruitment; quantitative trafficking assays; functional validation
weaknesses: Mechanistic details of Arf1-LRBA interaction unclear; limited structural insight
citation: Szentgyörgyi V, et al. J Cell Biol. 2024;223(11):e202401167
notes: Provides strong evidence for dynamic regulation over static scaffolding. Demonstrates conformational responsiveness to cellular GTPase states, supporting allosteric regulation hypothesis.

title: Molecular Dissection of Neurobeachin Function at Excitatory Synapses
authors: Repetto D, Brockhaus J, Rhee HJ, Lee C, Kilimann MW, Rhee J, Northoff LM, Guo W, Reissner C, Missler M
keyAssumptions: All domains contribute equally to function; domains work independently; full-length protein required for all functions
keyHypotheses: PH-BEACH complex is sufficient minimal functional unit; different domains provide specific regulatory inputs
strengths: Systematic domain dissection; multiple functional readouts; quantitative rescue experiments
weaknesses: Limited mechanistic insight into domain communication; focus on single protein family
citation: Repetto D, et al. Front Synaptic Neurosci. 2018;10:28
notes: Demonstrates PH-BEACH as integrated functional unit with regulatory cross-talk between domains. Strong support for allosteric network model where different domains provide regulatory inputs.

title: Allosteric properties of PH domains in Arf regulatory proteins
authors: Roy NS, Yohe ME, Randazzo PA, Gruschus JM
keyAssumptions: PH domains primarily function as membrane-binding modules; limited regulatory communication with other domains
keyHypotheses: PH domains function as allosteric regulators with context-dependent binding and conformational networks
strengths: Multiple biophysical approaches; demonstrates conformational networks; functional validation
weaknesses: Limited to Arf regulatory proteins; PH-BEACH coupling not directly studied
citation: Roy NS, et al. Cell Logist. 2016;6(2):e1181700
notes: Provides mechanistic framework for PH-BEACH allosteric coupling by establishing PH domains as allosteric elements capable of transmitting conformational changes.
